Award.AbstractNarration:
In many branches of mathematics one encounters sets of equations with symmetries -- transformations that take any solution of the equations to another solution. In this situation, it is often very useful to classify all solutions up to the action of these symmetries, two solutions considered equivalent if they are related by a symmetry transformation. Within the field of algebraic geometry, the theory known as geometric invariant theory provides a very good answer to this classification question. There is reason to suspect that the methods of geometric invariant theory extend to a much broader context. In particle physics, the universe is described as a set of solutions of some equations up to the action of a very large set of symmetries. This project aims to broaden the methods and results of geometric invariant theory and bring them to bear on a large set of classification problems in algebraic geometry, including some of those studied in high energy physics.

This project envisions a new general approach to moduli problems in algebraic geometry. The main technical tool is a special kind of stratification on an algebraic stack called a theta stratification. Theta stratifications are a common generalization of the Kempf-Ness stratification studied in geometric invariant theory and the Harder-Narasimhan stratification of the moduli space of vector bundles on a curve. Classically these stratifications were used, in the case of smooth stacks, to study the Betti numbers of the moduli stack of semistable objects. The project will pursue several generalizations of these results to situations where the stack is not necessarily smooth, and to extracting more subtle topological information about the stack. Examples include wall-crossing formulas for integrals of tautological K-theory classes, and more generally extracting information about the derived category of coherent sheaves on the stack and the semistable locus.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Beyond geometric invariant theory: project outcomes

In mathematics, the phrase "moduli problem" refers to the problem of understanding all possible "objects" of a certain kind, and especially how those objects depend on continuous parameters. For example, one might like to study polygons in the plane. Polygons are determined by the coordinates of their vertices. But, some possible assignments of coordinates to vertices do not actually define a polygon (e.g., if one vertex is inside the polygon spanned by the other vertices), and many different choices of coordinates for vertices lead to the same polygon in the sense that they differ by a rotation or translation of the plane. If one takes the set of all valid coordinate assignments, and identifies any two coordinate assignments that give the same polygon, one obtains an object, called a "moduli space." One can regard this moduli space as a (high dimensional) shape that has geometric features of its own. Many questions about the original objects (in this case, polygons) can be translated into geometric questions about this moduli space.

Algebraic geometry is a subfield of mathematics that studies shapes (called algebraic varieties) that can be defined by systems of polynomial equations. It is a very broad subject, with many connections and applications to other areas (differential geometry, representation theory, number theory, combinatorics, optimization). Beyond geometric invariant theory (GIT) is a program to develop a set of new tools for studying moduli problems which one can in principal apply to ANY moduli problem in algebraic geometry.

Geometric Invariant Theory (GIT) is a tool, developed in the 1970's, for analyzing moduli problems that can be described in terms of the orbits of some group action, as in the example of polygons above. This has been an incredibly useful tool, but many moduli spaces of recent interest in algebraic geometry cannot be described as orbit spaces, and thus lie outside the reach of ordinary GIT. The Beyond GIT program remedies this by generalizing and reinterpreting GIT from a more "intrinsic" perspective.


Intellectual Merit:

The Beyond GIT grant has supported the production of thirteen research papers and preprints, as well as two research notes that will soon be incorporated into papers. The main theorems established under this grant laid the groundwork for future research, and these results are currently being applied in several different areas of algebraic geometry.

The project set up the theory of "Theta-stability" for studying a moduli problem in algebraic geometry, which has two main pieces: 1) to construct "good moduli spaces" for semistable objects, and 2) to construct a special stratification of the moduli problem, called a Theta-stratification. To do this, the PI developed several foundational results in the theory of algebraic stacks (Tannaka duality, algebraicity of mapping stacks). The PI also developed several applications of the theory of Theta-stability to conjectures originating in mathematical physics (Verlinde formula, D-equivalence conjecture).


Broader impacts:

While supported by this grant, the PI has engaged in several activities to disseminate mathematical knowledge: giving three mini-courses outside the US, and developing interactive "concept maps" which can be used to make research mathematics accessible to a broader audience. The PI also co-organized a research experience for undergraduates on topics related to number theory and algebraic geometry, whose goal was to foster interest in higher mathematics. Finally, the PI began to develop research at the intersection of machine learning and pure mathematics, and to build connections to industry in that area.
